Aphids on Vegetables.overview: Aphids are small, soft-bodied insects that suck sap from plant tissues...
Aphids on Vegetables.symptoms: Aphid feeding results in an overall loss of plant vigor...
Aphids on Vegetables.management: Thoroughly scout crops and weeds for signs or symptoms of aphids...

Armyworms on Vegetables.overview: Armyworms can be found all over the United States...
Armyworms on Vegetables.symptoms: Larvae feed on leaves with chewing mouthparts...
Armyworms on Vegetables.management: Keep crop area weed-free, till residues and control weeds...

Blister Beetle.overview: Blister beetles in the genera Epicuata are found throughout North America...
Blister Beetle.symptoms: Adults feed on plant foliage and blossoms...
Blister Beetle.management: Blister beetle populations are influenced by grasshopper populations...

Beet Leafhopper.overview: Beet leafhoppers have wedge-shaped bodies varying in color from pale green, gray, or tan...
Beet Leafhopper.symptoms: Adults and nymphs feed with piercing sucking mouthparts, which can cause shriveled and 'burned' leaves...
Beet Leafhopper.management: Exclude leafhoppers with floating row covers, shade tomato and pepper plants, remove plant debris...

Colorado Potato Beetle.overview: Adults are about the same size and shape as a lady beetle but with yellow and black stripes...
Colorado Potato Beetle.symptoms: Adults and larvae feed with chewing mouthparts and can defoliate plants...
Colorado Potato Beetle.management: Rotate crops to non-solanaceous crops, keep crop area free of solanaceous weeds...

Western Striped and Spotted Cucumber Bee.overview: Adult western striped cucumber beetles are about 1/3 inches long, with black heads and yellow and black-striped wings...
Western Striped and Spotted Cucumber Bee.symptoms: Feeding scars on soft rinds of fruits, especially the undersides. Holes in stems and leaves. Destroyed flowers...
Western Striped and Spotted Cucumber Bee.management: Hand-pick cucumber beetles, plant resistant varieties, use row covers and mulches...

Spotted Cucumber Beetle.overview: Adults have a black head, legs, and antennae. They have ovoid yellow-green bodies with 12 black spots on the wings...
Spotted Cucumber Beetle.symptoms: In hemp, adults chew on leaves, creating irregular-shaped holes. Damage is considered minor...
Spotted Cucumber Beetle.management: Keep crop area weed-free, use plastic or organic mulches, destroy crop residues after harvest...

Cutworms on Vegetables.overview: Cutworms belong to a large group of night-flying moths in the Noctuidae family...
Cutworms on Vegetables.symptoms: Larvae feed with chewing mouthparts and can clip off seedlings at the soil line...
Cutworms on Vegetables.management: Remove cool-season weeds, use fall tillage to expose overwintering pupae, protect seedlings with collars...

False Chinch Bug.overview: On adults, the head, thorax, and anterior portion of the wings are brownish gray and the posterior portion of the wings are whitish-clear...
False Chinch Bug.symptoms: Adults and nymphs feed with piercing-sucking mouthparts. Large numbers of aggregating adults can cause plants to wilt and die rapidly...
False Chinch Bug.management: Scout field edges that may contain mustards, look for aggregations on plants, keep plants well irrigated...

Flea Beetles.overview: Flea beetles are common and problematic in Utah, affecting vegetable crops and ornamental plants...
Flea Beetles.symptoms: Small, round holes or pits in leaves and cotyledons...
Flea Beetles.management: Adjust planting times, promote healthy plant growth, use trap crops and row covers...

Tomato and Tobacco Hornworms.overview: Adults are large moths also known as sphinx, hawk, or hummingbird moths. Larvae are large, cylindrical and usually green...
Tomato and Tobacco Hornworms.symptoms: Larvae use chewing mouthparts to feed on leaves, blossoms, stems, and fruits, leaving behind dark green or black frass...
Tomato and Tobacco Hornworms.management: Plow field after harvest to destroy pupae, rotate crops with non-host plants, handpick larvae at dawn or dusk...

Thrips on Vegetables.overview: Thrips overwinter as adults in plant debris and protected areas. In the spring, they become active and move into fields...
Thrips on Vegetables.symptoms: White flecks or silvery scars on foliage, dark fecal spots on leaves, distorted leaf growth, reduced bulb size in onions...
Thrips on Vegetables.management: Plow plant debris under after harvest, inspect transplants for thrips, remove weeds within fields, place mulch, plant resistant crop varieties...

hosts: Weeds including pigweed and shepherd's purse
Potato Leafhopper.overview: Adults are wedge-shaped, light green in color, and widest at the head with an elongated body...
Potato Leafhopper.symptoms: Adults and nymphs feed with piercing-sucking mouthparts, causing white-flecked injury (stippling) on foliage. Heavy feeding can lead to scorching...
Potato Leafhopper.management: Manage weeds to reduce leafhopper populations, monitor symptoms such as curling leaves and stippling, apply insecticides when necessary...

Two-Spotted Spider Mite.overview: Adults are tiny, with a yellowish-clear body and two dark spots on either side of its back...
Two-Spotted Spider Mite.symptoms: Stippled (small yellow spots) leaves, generalized bronzing or reddish discoloration, reduced plant vigor, premature leaf drop...
Two-Spotted Spider Mite.management: Keep plants healthy, wash mites off plants with strong water stream, avoid malathion and pyrethroid insecticides, attract predatory mites...

Corn Earworm / Tomato Fruitworm.overview: Corn earworm larvae feed on all plant parts, including fruits and kernels. Damage can result in decreased pollination and hollowed-out fruits...
Corn Earworm / Tomato Fruitworm.symptoms: Tunnels in kernels and fruits filled with frass, direct damage to stems, foliage, and corn silk, premature fruit ripening, fruit rot...
Corn Earworm / Tomato Fruitworm.management: Avoid planting solanaceous crops near post-silking corn fields, use clothespins on corn silk, plant resistant varieties, remove infested plant debris...

Tomato Russet Mite.overview: Adults and nymphs have cigar-shaped, yellowish-tan or pink bodies and require a microscope to observe...
Tomato Russet Mite.symptoms: Bronzing or 'russeting' of stems, leaves, and fruits, yellowing, curling, deflated leaves, and longitudinal cracks on fruits...
Tomato Russet Mite.management: Use clean transplants, avoid planting during hot, dry periods, remove infested debris, clean tools after use...

Whiteflies (Family: Aleyrodidae).overview: Adults are tiny with bright white wings and yellow-orange heads. Immature stages are pale, translucent, and mostly immobile...
Whiteflies (Family: Aleyrodidae).symptoms: Leaves turn yellow, appear dry, or fall off plants. Whiteflies also excrete honeydew, causing sticky surfaces or sooty mold growth...
Whiteflies (Family: Aleyrodidae).management: Attract and conserve natural enemies, inspect transplants, remove heavily infested plants, use biocontrol such as Encarsia sp....
insecticides: clarified hydrophobic extract of neem oil

Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.overview: Alfalfa mosaic virus (AMV) is in the genus Alfamovirus and is spread by aphids...
Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.symptoms: Yellow mosaic or calico patterns on foliage, stunted plants, tuber necrosis, bright yellow blotches interspersed with green...
Alfalfa Mosaic Virus.management: Avoid planting potatoes or hemp near alfalfa fields, remove plants with positive diagnosis...

Bacterial Canker.overview: Bacterial canker disease is caused by Clavibacter michiganensis subsp. michiganensis. It is primarily an economic concern for tomato...
Bacterial Canker.symptoms: Wilting in young plants, yellow leaf margins ('firing'), white spots with dark centers on fruit, vascular discoloration in stems...
Bacterial Canker.management: Source disease-free seed, clean and disinfect equipment, avoid overwatering, rotate crops, remove solanaceous weeds, deep plow soil...
insecticides: Copper-based products effective in greenhouse transplant production

Bacterial Speck.overview: Bacterial speck (Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato) infections occur during cool (63 to 75°F) wet conditions...
Bacterial Speck.symptoms: Brown to black spots with a yellow halo on leaves, scabby pinpoint-like spots on fruit, damage does not penetrate into flesh...
Bacterial Speck.management: Start examining undersides of leaves soon after planting, delay planting until wet conditions pass, avoid overhead irrigation, rotate crops...

hosts: Several other wild and economic hosts
Beet Curly Top Virus.overview: Beet Curly Top Virus (BCTV) is a Curtovirus in the Geminiviridae family, vectored by the beet leafhopper (BLH)...
Beet Curly Top Virus.symptoms: Young infected plants usually die, stunted growth, thick curled leaves, dull yellow color with purple veins, prematurely ripened fruit...
Beet Curly Top Virus.management: Implement shading, use row covers, double plant to reduce losses, manage weeds that serve as alternative hosts for BLH...
insecticides: Avoid chemical treatments due to BLH migration

Big Bud.overview: Big bud is caused by a small bacterium called phytoplasma, infecting plant vascular tissue and causing abnormal growth...
Big Bud.symptoms: Swollen flower buds, distorted flower and leaf growth, short and thick apical stems, yellow discoloration of foliage...
Big Bud.management: Remove infected plants, clear weeds that host leafhoppers...

Blossom End Rot.overview: Blossom-end rot (BER) is a physiological disorder caused by calcium deficiency and aggravated by moisture imbalances...
Blossom End Rot.symptoms: Water-soaked discoloration on the blossom end, leathery dark brown or black lesions, sunken fruit, potential secondary infections...
Blossom End Rot.management: Use deep, infrequent irrigation to maintain uniform soil moisture, avoid ammonium-based nitrogen fertilizers, protect roots from injury, apply mulch...

Damping-Off.overview: Damping-off is caused by soilborne organisms including Pythium, Rhizoctonia, Fusarium, and Phytophthora species...
Damping-Off.symptoms: Circular bare spots in seed flats due to seedling death, pinched brown or black stems, seedlings tipping over...
Damping-Off.management: Disinfect growing benches and containers, use sterile potting mix, avoid excessive irrigation...
insecticides: Seed treatments available, fungicides can reduce incidence

Early Blight.overview: Early blight is a fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani, affecting mature vines, tubers, and fruit...
Early Blight.symptoms: Pinpoint brown or black spots on lower leaves, yellow halo around spots, concentric rings in lesions, sunken stem and tuber lesions...
Early Blight.management: Use crop rotations, source disease-free transplants, destroy volunteer plants, plow down debris, maintain plant vigor, avoid prolonged leaf wetness...
insecticides: Fungicide spray programs initiated in early August if lesions appear

Fusarium Crown/Root Rot.overview: Fusarium species causing this disease are soilborne pathogens that persist in soil for years...
Fusarium Crown/Root Rot.symptoms: Rotting and necrotic roots, discoloration and softening of crown tissue, stunted growth, wilting and plant death...
Fusarium Crown/Root Rot.management: Remove infected plants, sanitize equipment, sterilize soil, rotate crops with non-susceptible varieties, ensure proper soil drainage...
insecticides: No fungicides available, prevention is key

Fusarium Wilt.overview: Fusarium wilt is caused by Fusarium oxysporum, with formae speciales specific to individual crops...
Fusarium Wilt.symptoms: Foliar chlorosis, wilting, red to purple leaf discoloration, stunted growth, brown vascular tissue, reduced yield...
Fusarium Wilt.management: Use certified disease-free seed, plant resistant varieties, improve water drainage, clean equipment to minimize spread...
insecticides: No chemical controls available, prevention is key

Late Blight.overview: Late blight is caused by Phytophthora infestans and spreads rapidly under wet, moderate temperatures...
Late Blight.symptoms: Greasy-gray blotches on leaves and stems that turn black, hard brown blotchy lesions on fruit and tubers extending into flesh...
Late Blight.management: Scout early after planting, monitor wet field areas, eliminate infected plant debris, avoid overhead irrigation, rotate crops...
insecticides: Fungicides necessary where the disease has occurred in the past

Root-Knot Nematodes.overview: Microscopic roundworms that enter plants through root tips, moving within roots until they find preferred feeding spots...
Root-Knot Nematodes.symptoms: Chlorosis, stunting resembling nutrient deficiency, galled roots that may merge into large tumors...
Root-Knot Nematodes.management: Use tolerant varieties, keep infested fields fallow, remove weeds, roto-till fallow areas regularly, apply Telone fumigation in commercial fields...
insecticides: No chemical options available for non-commercial fields

Phytophthora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots.overview: Caused by various Phytophthora species, thriving in water-saturated soil and infecting plant roots...
Phytophthora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots.symptoms: Bruised, soft, rotted seedlings, chocolate-brown lesions on roots and stems, yellowing leaves, wilting and plant death in patches...
Phytophthora Root, Stem, and Crown Rots.management: Watch for symptoms early, improve soil drainage, manage water use, rotate crops, use resistant varieties...
insecticides: No chemical control, prevention through water management

Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.overview: Powdery mildew is easily identifiable as white, powdery patches on leaves. It thrives in warm temperatures, humid canopies, and poor airflow...
Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.symptoms: White, powdery fungal growth on leaves, stems, and petioles; yellowing and wilting of leaves, potential fruit sunscald and yield loss...
Powdery Mildew on Vegetables.management: Plant resistant varieties, remove infected plant material after harvest, improve air circulation, use morning irrigation, switch to drip irrigation...
insecticides: Fungicides available, repeated applications every 7–10 days

Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.overview: TMV and ToMV are Tobamoviruses spread by seed, grafting, human handling, and tobacco products...
Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.symptoms: Abnormally shaped fruit, fruit lesions, reduced fruit size, distorted growth points, yellowing leaves, stem distortion...
Tobacco Mosaic Virus & Tomato Mosaic Vir.management: Remove infected plants immediately, source disease-free seed, grow resistant varieties, disinfect tools, avoid tobacco handling...
insecticides: No chemical controls available, rely on sanitation and resistant cultivars

hosts: Several other vegetable and weed hosts
Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus.overview: Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus (TSWV) is a Tospovirus spread by thrips species and affects plants throughout the growing season...
Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus.symptoms: Stunted plants, necrotic leaf spots, calico patterns on mature fruit, necrotic rings on fruit, discoloration of seeds...
Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus.management: Monitor thrips activity, remove and destroy infected plants, purchase healthy transplants, use resistant varieties, control weeds...
insecticides: No chemical controls available, rely on thrips management and resistant cultivars

hosts: Many crop, ornamental, and weed species
Verticillium Wilt.overview: Verticillium wilt is caused by fungi Verticillium dahliae and Verticillium albo-atrum, persisting for years in soil...
Verticillium Wilt.symptoms: Leaves yellow and die from the bottom up, decreased fruit quality, premature wilting, symptoms appearing on one side of the plant...
Verticillium Wilt.management: Use resistant varieties, plant on raised beds, avoid planting in infected fields, prevent root injury, practice sanitation, rotate crops...
insecticides: No direct chemical control, rely on prevention and resistant cultivars

Cercospora Leaf Spot (Frogeye).overview: Caused by Cercospora capsici and C. melongenae, producing circular chlorotic lesions with necrotic centers...
Cercospora Leaf Spot (Frogeye).symptoms: Small chlorotic lesions, necrotic centers with concentric rings, defoliation, reduced fruit size...
Cercospora Leaf Spot (Frogeye).management: Use protectant fungicide spray programs, remove infected debris, rotate crops, apply mulch, use furrow or drip irrigation...
insecticides: Fungicide treatments based on a calendar schedule

Choanephora Blight (Wet Rot).overview: Caused by Choanephora cucurbitarum, occurring in tropical regions with high humidity and rainfall...
Choanephora Blight (Wet Rot).symptoms: Water-soaked areas on leaves, blighted apical growing points, dark gray fungal growth, silvery spine-like fungal structures, black soft rot in fruit...
Choanephora Blight (Wet Rot).management: Few management techniques available; fungicide sprays may help reduce disease damage...
insecticides: Limited fungicide options, rely on environmental control

Gray Leaf Spot.overview: Caused by Stemphylium solani and S. lycopersici, leading to small red to brown spots on foliage...
Gray Leaf Spot.symptoms: Expanding lesions with white to gray centers and dark margins, yellowing leaves, defoliation, does not affect fruit...
Gray Leaf Spot.management: Remove infected plant debris, improve ventilation for seedlings, apply fungicide treatments...

Phomopsis Blight.overview: Caused by Phomopsis vexans, affecting seedlings, leaves, stems, and fruit, leading to significant plant decline...
Phomopsis Blight.symptoms: Dark-brown lesions on stems, dry rot, collapsing seedlings, circular gray-brown lesions on leaves, severe defoliation, mummified fruit...
Phomopsis Blight.management: Sow high-quality seed, remove infected plants, rotate crops, mulch and furrow irrigate to reduce pathogen spread...
